xyz.acygn.mokapot

Interface Standin<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type that this object is standing in for.
    All Superinterfaces:
    LongReference, ProxyOrWrapper<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    IndirectStandin

    public interface Standin<T>
extends LongReference, ProxyOrWrapper<T>
    A standin is a class that's used in place of another class, to transparently add functionality. In the case of this library, we're adding the following functionalities: the ability for the class's fields to be stored remotely on another machine (implemented via running methods remotely whenever the storage method extends ForwardingStandinStorage); the ability to serialise the object into a "description" of that object (which holds the values of each copiable field in serialised format, plus references to the noncopiable fields); the ability to conditionally attach a finalizer that saves the object's description in its location manager once it becomes locally dead; and the ability to invoke methods indirectly via a "method code" number. (Many of these abilities are implemented indirectly via the StandinStorage class.)

    At present, there are two main ways that this interface can be implemented; by composition, or by inheritance. The inheritance-based method is more efficient, and used in cases when we're creating a standin directly; the standin class is created by code generation, extending an existing class and implementing this interface. In cases where there's a need to apply the operations normally implemented by a standin to an object that already exists, a composition-based method can be used instead, in which a temporary IndirectStandin object is created that applies its actions indirectly to the original object. Note that in the latter case, not all standin actions are guaranteed to have the correct semantics if any references directly to the original object (rather than via the standin) exist.

    An inheritance-based standin is sometimes a long reference (whether it's a long reference or a short reference is a status that can change dynamically over the course of a program's execution). This status (long or short) is stored indirectly via the standin's storage method. Standins implement the LongReference interface as an approximation, but this is not always correct, and code that needs to distinguish short references from long references will typically need a third case for standins.

    Because the Standin interface sometimes has to be implemented retroactively via editing it into classes from outside this library that were created with no knowledge of it, every method should take an Authorisation parameter in case an existing method happens to have the same name. Depending on whether the method would be safe to call from arbitrary code, some methods will verify the parameter, whereas others will allow a null authorisation; this will be mentioned in the method documentation.

    Author:
    Alex Smith
    See Also:
    StandinStorage

      • Methods inherited from interface xyz.acygn.mokapot.ProxyOrWrapper

        getReferentClass

    • Method Detail

      • getStorage

        StandinStorage<T> getStorage(Authorisation auth)
        Gets the mechanism that this standin uses to store its data. This should be stored on a private mutable field of the standin, and can typically simply be a direct getter method (that checks the provided authorisation and then returns the field).

        The default value of the standin storage field should be a new object of class TrivialStandinStorage.

        Parameters:
        auth - An authorisation, for namespacing purposes; need not be verified (no information in a StandinStorage object is secret, although much of it is not really intelligible outside this package) and thus can be null.
        Returns:
        This standin's storage mechanism.

      • setStorage

        void setStorage(StandinStorage<T> storage,
                Authorisation auth)
         throws UnsupportedOperationException
        Sets the mechanism that this standin uses to store its data. This should be stored on a private mutable field of the standin, and can typically simply be a direct setter method (that checks the provided authorisation and then returns the field). As an exception, standins for Copiable objects will never have their standin storage set (because copiable objects can't be long references, can't be long-referenced, and can't be migrated), so this method will not be called in this case and may error out if called.

        Note that although this method should not have side effects, the field storage must. Most notably, each method of the standin whose purpose is to access the standin's data (i.e. the methods of the superclass and the various implemented interfaces) should first check to see if the field in question contains an object that implements ForwardingStandinStorage. If it does, the method should forward its parameters rather than just calling the method on the referent (as would be used when in stored-in-self status).

        The standin storage object can also have other side effects (e.g. it can have a nontrivial finaliser). This is handled automatically, though, and need not be handled by the standin itself.

        Parameters:
        storage - The new storage mechanism.
        auth - An authorisation, for namespacing and verification purposes; cannot be null (and must be verified by the implementation of this method using Authorisation#verify).
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - If this class is Copiable

      • descriptionSize

        ObjectDescription.Size descriptionSize(boolean nullable,
                                       Authorisation auth)
        Calculates the size of a description of this object, excluding its class. This is used to determine how much space to allocate when incorporating this object into a description. Note that this method should assume that the object will be stored as a complete description of its fields, even if it's of a class that's more normally marshalled as a reference.

        Note that it is not correct to implement this method using ClassKnowledge#descriptionSize; that method will return the size of one reference in the case that the object would normally be marshalled via reference, and will call this method to determine the size in most other cases.

        Parameters:
        nullable - Whether the description will be produced in a format that has a distinct null value.
        auth - An authorisation, for namespacing and perhaps verification purposes; must be verified if describing the object could be used to bypass security on its fields, and may be verified in other circumstances too.
        Returns:
        The size of the description.
        See Also:
        ClassKnowledge.descriptionSize(java.util.function.Supplier, boolean)

      • describeInto

        default void describeInto(DescriptionOutput desc,
                          Authorisation auth)
                   throws IOException
        Produces a description (that is, a semi-serialised shallow copy) of this object, excluding its class. The description is formed via serialising the object itself and (recursively) any copiable fields of the object, except that noncopiable fields are not serialised and rather remain as references, and returned via appending it to an existing object description. The description can subsequently be used to produce either a shallow copy of the object, or a marshalled form of the object.

        This library will only call the method in situations where the standin is in stored-in-self status (i.e. its fields are the canonical location in which the object that the standin is standing in for its data).

        Unlike with ClassKnowledge#describeFieldInto (which is implemented, for copiable classes, in terms of this method), this should always use a format that doesn't have a special case for null (and can assume that the object is non-null; obviously it is, because this method is being called on it!) The caller will encode null (or its opposite) itself if necessary.

        The default implementation calls #writeTo. This is only correct in cases where the referent is deeply copiable, i.e. has no noncopiable references anywhere after recursively expanding fields (and for which recursively expanding fields is a finite process). In other cases, the default implementation will need to be overridden.

        Parameters:
        desc - The description to append the description of this object to.
        auth - An authorisation, for namespacing and perhaps verification purposes; must be verified if describing the object could be used to bypass security on its fields, and may be verified in other circumstances too.
        Throws:
        IOException - If something goes wrong writing to the description
        See Also:
        ClassKnowledge.describeFieldInto(xyz.acygn.mokapot.wireformat.DescriptionOutput, java.lang.Object, boolean), writeTo(java.io.DataOutput, xyz.acygn.mokapot.Authorisation)

      • writeTo

        void writeTo(DataOutput sink,
             Authorisation auth)
      throws UnsupportedOperationException,
             IOException
        Writes a description of this object directly to a data output sink. This excludes the object's class, and is an optional operation, that only needs to be implemented in cases where the standin's referent is deeply copiable. (It should not be called on objects which can't be completely serialised down to a flat structure.)
        Parameters:
        sink - The sink to write the description to.
        auth - An authorisation, for namespacing and perhaps verification purposes; must be verified if describing the object could be used to bypass security on its fields, and may be verified in other circumstances too.
        Throws:
        IOException - If something goes wrong writing the description
        UnsupportedOperationException - If this standin is not deeply copiable

      • replaceWithReproduction

        void replaceWithReproduction(ReadableDescription desc,
                             Authorisation auth)
                      throws IOException
        Replaces the content of this standin's referent with a reproduction of the given description. In other words, we're effectively "overwriting" the content of this standin. This method is typically called just before the standin becomes the canonical place to store data for the object it's standing in for (either because it's about to enter stored-in-self status, or else because its local location manager wants to use it to store data).

        If the referent has been dropped, this method instead creates a new referent from the given description.

        Parameters:
        desc - The description to reproduce.
        auth - An authorisation, for namespacing and verification purposes; cannot be null (and must be verified by the implementation of this method using Authorisation#verify).
        Throws:
        IOException - If the description appears to be corrupted

      • invoke

        Object invoke(long methodCode,
              Object[] methodArguments,
              Authorisation auth)
       throws Throwable
        Invokes a method directly on the local referent of this standin. Unlike using getReferent, the method is not intercepted by the standin even if it normally would be (e.g. a method can be forwarded to the location manager if called directly on the standin, and yet called on the standin without forwarding if called indirectly via invoke); this mechanism prevents an infinite forwarding loop in the case where the standin forwards the method to the location manager, but the location manager forwards it back to the original standin.
        Parameters:
        methodCode - The method code of the method to run (calculated using the actual class of the standin's referent, i.e. T).
        methodArguments - The arguments of the method.
        auth - An authorisation, for namespacing and verification purposes; cannot be null (and must be verified by the implementation of this method using Authorisation#verify).
        Returns:
        The return value of the method.
        Throws:
        Throwable - If the invoked method throws an exception, then this method throws the same exception.

      • getReferent

        T getReferent(Authorisation auth)
        Gets the underlying object behind this standin. For a composition-based standin, this is a different object. For an inheritance-based object, this is the standin itself; as such, it must return this. This method can safely be used to determine whether a standin is inheritance-based, via checking to see if the return value is equal to the standin itself using reference equality.

        Bear in mind that this is a very low-level operation; the object in question might not be currently in use to store the standin's data, for example. As such, it's probably useful only in cases where the referent is already known to be local (e.g. when creating a location manager for it).

        Parameters:
        auth - An authorisation, for namespacing and verification purposes; cannot be null (and must be verified by the implementation of this method using Authorisation#verify).
        Returns:
        The local referent of this standin.

      • dropResources

        default void dropResources(Authorisation auth)
        Drops any unnecessary references to data that this standin might currently be holding. This is called by the location manager when the standin isn't currently being used to store data (i.e. isStoredLocally() in the storage manager is false).

        It's to some extent up to the standin just how much it wants to drop. Anything that won't be useful in the future (e.g. references in mutable fields) almost certainly should be dropped; in the case of a composition-based standin, its referent must be dropped (in order that the caller can get better guarantees about sharing). An inheritance-based standin might want to hold onto immutable fields so that less time is spent loading them if the data is migrated back into the standin, and/or so that it can code methods locally if they use only those fields.

        The default implementation verifies the authorisation and the state of the standin's storage and does nothing else. Calling into this default implementation is a sensible way for implementations of this interface to verify the parameters. The default implementation throws unchecked exceptions upon violations of the calling convention; NullPointerException if the authorisation is null, IllegalStateException if the standin's data is currently held locally, or whatever exception happened trying to verify the authorisation. This is not part of the API contract of this method, and implementations of this method may choose to report errors in calling it via some other means.

        Parameters:
        auth - An authorisation, for namespacing and verification purposes; cannot be null (and must be verified by the implementation of this method using Authorisation#verify).
